issues.text: Was the reference made by the parties to the arbitrators a specific reference, that is, a reference inviting the arbitrators to decide certain questions of law submitted to them?

anchor.surface_text: Was the reference made by the parties to the arbitrators a specific reference, that is, a reference inviting the arbitrators to decide certain questions of law submitted to them? If the reference is of a specific question of law, even if the award is erroneous, the decision being of arbitrators selected by the parties to adjudicate upon those questions, the award will bind the parties.

issues.text: Whether the award of the arbitrators is erroneous on the face thereof so as to permit it being set aside?

anchor.surface_text: set aside an award on the ground of an error on the face thereof only when in the award or in any document incorporated with it, as for instance, a memorandum appended by the arbitrators, stating the reasons for his decision, there is found some legal proposition which is the basis of the award and which is erroneous... The award may, therefore, be set aside if it be demonstrated to be erroneous on the face of it.

issues.text: Whether the arbitrators could ignore the express covenants of the contract and award additional establishment and contingency charges to the Agents?

anchor.surface_text: on the basis of quantum meruit. The High Court held that there was no specific reference... Granting that the Agents had incurred this additional expenditure under the head establishment and contingencies, when the contract expressly stipulated for payment of charges at rates specified therein, we fail to appreciate on what ground the arbitrators could ignore the express covenants between the parties, and award to the Agents amounts which the Union of India had not agreed to pay to the Agents.

issues.text: Whether the arbitrators had authority to award additional mandi and financing charges in excess of the stipulated rates?

anchor.surface_text: Section 56 of the Indian Contract Act provides A contract to do an act which, after the contract... But the terms of the contract, stipulating the rate at which the financing and overhead charges were to be paid under cl. 13 a read with cl. 12 b, remained binding so long as the contract was not abandoned or altered by mutual agreement, and the arbitrators had no authority to award any amount in excess of the amount expressly stipulated to be paid.

issues.text: Whether the changed circumstances due to World War II frustrated the contract or justified ignoring its express terms?

anchor.surface_text: Performance of the contract had not become impossible or unlawful the contract was in fact performed... A contract is not frustrated merely because the circumstances in which the contract was made, are altered... there is no general rule to which recourse may be had... on account of an uncontemplated turn of events since the date of the contract.

issues.text: Whether the Agents are entitled to compensation on the basis of quantum meruit despite the express contractual stipulation for remuneration?

anchor.surface_text: Compensation quantum meruit is awarded for work done or services rendered, when the price thereof is not fixed by a contract. For work done or services rendered pursuant to the terms of a contract, compensation quantum meruit cannot be awarded where the contract provides for the consideration payable in that behalf... an express stipulation governing the relations between the parties under a contract, cannot be displaced by assuming that the stipulation is not reasonable.

issues.text: Whether Section 222 of the Indian Contract Act entitles the Agents to indemnity for excess charges?

anchor.surface_text: Relying upon s. 222 of the Indian Contract Act, by which duty to indemnify the agent against the consequences of all lawful acts done in exercise of the authority conferred, is imposed upon the employer, the arbitrators could not award compensation to the agents in excess of the expressly stipulated consideration. The claim made by the Agents was not for indemnity... but a claim for enhancement of the rate of the agreed consideration.

issues.text: Whether there is a bar of res judicata by reason of the decision in Letters Patent Appeal No. 31 of 1953?

anchor.surface_text: a bar of res judicata by reason of the decision in the Letters Patent Appeal No. 31 of 1953, has, in our judgment, no force. The Subordinate Judge set aside the award on the ground that there had been judicial misconduct committed by the umpire and also on the view that the claims made, as described in Schedules B and D, were not outside the competence of the arbitrators.

issues.text: Whether the Government of India was estopped from repudiating the claims for enhanced rates based on alleged verbal assurances?

anchor.surface_text: was estopped from repudiating their claim set out in Schedules B and C, in view of all the facts... Assuming that the Agents relied upon assurances alleged to be given by the Director in-charge of Purchases, in the absence of an express covenant modifying the contract which governed the relations of the Agents with the Government of India, vague assurances could not modify the contract.

arguments.claim: The reference to arbitrators was a specific reference on questions of law, making the award binding even if erroneous.

anchor.surface_text: At the hearing of the appeal, counsel for the Agents sought to support the award on the plea that certain questions had been specifically referred to the arbitrators, and it was open to the arbitrators to make the award which they made, on the basis of quantum meruit.

arguments.claim: No res judicata from prior appeal.

anchor.surface_text: a bar of res judicata by reason of the decision in the Letters Patent Appeal No. 31 of 1953,

holdings.text: The reference made by the parties to the arbitrators was a general reference and not a specific reference on any question of law.

anchor.surface_text: We agree, therefore, with the view of the High Court that the reference made, was a general reference and no a specific reference on any question of law. The award may, therefore, be set aside if it be demonstrated to be erroneous on the face of it.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Reference per letters dated July 1, 1946, August 2, 1952 was general under cl.20; issues raised by arbitrators do not convert to specific; no evidence of submitting specific legal questions.

holdings.text: The award of the arbitrators is erroneous on the face thereof and liable to be set aside.

anchor.surface_text: set aside an award on the ground of an error on the face thereof only when in the award or in any document incorporated with it, as for instance, a memorandum appended by the arbitrators, stating the reasons for his decision, there is found some legal proposition which is the basis of the award and which is erroneous...

holdings.reasoning_summary: Arbitrators stated erroneous legal basis by ignoring express contract terms for payments; applies doctrine of error apparent on face from precedents like Champsey Bhara.

holdings.text: The arbitrators could not ignore the express covenants of the contract and award additional establishment and contingency charges to the Agents.

anchor.surface_text: on the basis of quantum meruit. The High Court held that there was no specific reference... Granting that the Agents had incurred this additional expenditure under the head establishment and contingencies, when the contract expressly stipulated for payment of charges at rates specified therein, we fail to appreciate on what ground the arbitrators could ignore the express covenants between the parties, and award to the Agents amounts which the Union of India had not agreed to pay to the Agents.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cl.14(a) read with cl.12(b) expressly stipulates rates paid; no basis to exceed agreed amounts.

holdings.text: The arbitrators had no authority to award additional mandi and financing charges in excess of the stipulated rates.

anchor.surface_text: Section 56 of the Indian Contract Act provides A contract to do an act which, after the contract... But the terms of the contract, stipulating the rate at which the financing and overhead charges were to be paid under cl. 13 a read with cl. 12 b, remained binding so long as the contract was not abandoned or altered by mutual agreement, and the arbitrators had no authority to award any amount in excess of the amount expressly stipulated to be paid.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cl.13(a) read with cl.12(b) fixes rates; binding unless altered; evidence of price rise irrelevant.

holdings.text: The changed circumstances due to World War II did not frustrate the contract or justify ignoring its express terms.

anchor.surface_text: Performance of the contract had not become impossible or unlawful the contract was in fact performed... A contract is not frustrated merely because the circumstances in which the contract was made, are altered... there is no general rule to which recourse may be had... on account of an uncontemplated turn of events since the date of the contract.

holdings.reasoning_summary: S.56 applies only to impossibility/unlawfulness; contract performed post-1942 modification aware of war; no general equity to vary terms; follows English/Indian precedents rejecting broad frustration.

holdings.text: The Agents are not entitled to compensation on the basis of quantum meruit despite the express contractual stipulation for remuneration.

anchor.surface_text: Compensation quantum meruit is awarded for work done or services rendered, when the price thereof is not fixed by a contract. For work done or services rendered pursuant to the terms of a contract, compensation quantum meruit cannot be awarded where the contract provides for the consideration payable in that behalf... an express stipulation governing the relations between the parties under a contract, cannot be displaced by assuming that the stipulation is not reasonable.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Quantum meruit implies contract only absent express price; cannot override stipulated rates.

holdings.text: Section 222 of the Indian Contract Act does not entitle the Agents to indemnity for excess charges.

anchor.surface_text: Relying upon s. 222 of the Indian Contract Act, by which duty to indemnify the agent against the consequences of all lawful acts done in exercise of the authority conferred, is imposed upon the employer, the arbitrators could not award compensation to the agents in excess of the expressly stipulated consideration. The claim made by the Agents was not for indemnity... but a claim for enhancement of the rate of the agreed consideration.

holdings.reasoning_summary: S.222 covers consequences of lawful acts under authority, not excess over agreed rates or enhancement claims.

holdings.text: There is no bar of res judicata by reason of the decision in Letters Patent Appeal No. 31 of 1953.

anchor.surface_text: a bar of res judicata by reason of the decision in the Letters Patent Appeal No. 31 of 1953, has, in our judgment, no force. The Subordinate Judge set aside the award on the ground that there had been judicial misconduct committed by the umpire and also on the view that the claims made, as described in Schedules B and D, were not outside the competence of the arbitrators.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Prior decision set aside award on misconduct and partial jurisdiction grounds; no conclusive adjudication on Sch.B/C competence.

holdings.text: The Government of India was not estopped from repudiating the claims for enhanced rates based on alleged verbal assurances.

anchor.surface_text: was estopped from repudiating their claim set out in Schedules B and C, in view of all the facts... Assuming that the Agents relied upon assurances alleged to be given by the Director in-charge of Purchases, in the absence of an express covenant modifying the contract which governed the relations of the Agents with the Government of India, vague assurances could not modify the contract.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Vague verbal assurances by agent insufficient to modify express contract absent express covenant.

holdings.text: The claims in Schedules B and C were within the competence of the arbitrators under cl.20.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court in appeal under the Letters Patent, did confirm the order, setting aside the award but there was no binding decision between the parties that the claim described in Sch. B... was within the competence of the arbitrators... according to the High Court... it was not necessary to express any opinion whether the claim in Sch. C was within the competence...

holdings.reasoning_summary: Prior courts held Sch.B within scope; Sch.C not conclusively excluded; no res judicata bar.

anchor.surface_text: We, accordingly, agree with the view of the High Court that the Award of the arbitrators was liable to be set aside because of an error apparent on the face of the award.

anchor.surface_text: We agree, therefore, with the view of the High Court that the reference made, was a general reference and no a specific reference on any question of law. The award may, therefore, be set aside if it be demonstrated to be erroneous on the face of it.
We, accordingly, agree with the view of the High Court that the Award of the arbitrators was liable to be set aside because of an error apparent on the face of the award.

anchor.surface_text: on the basis of quantum meruit. The High Court held that there was no specific reference... Granting that the Agents had incurred this additional expenditure under the head establishment and contingencies, when the contract expressly stipulated for payment of charges at rates specified therein, we fail to appreciate on what ground the arbitrators could ignore the express covenants between the parties, and award to the Agents amounts which the Union of India had not agreed to pay to the Agents.
We, accordingly, agree with the view of the High Court that the Award of the arbitrators was liable to be set aside because of an error apparent on the face of the award.

anchor.surface_text: Section 56 of the Indian Contract Act provides A contract to do an act which, after the contract... But the terms of the contract, stipulating the rate at which the financing and overhead charges were to be paid under cl. 13 a read with cl. 12 b, remained binding so long as the contract was not abandoned or altered by mutual agreement, and the arbitrators had no authority to award any amount in excess of the amount expressly stipulated to be paid.
We, accordingly, agree with the view of the High Court that the Award of the arbitrators was liable to be set aside because of an error apparent on the face of the award.

anchor.surface_text: Compensation quantum meruit is awarded for work done or services rendered, when the price thereof is not fixed by a contract. For work done or services rendered pursuant to the terms of a contract, compensation quantum meruit cannot be awarded where the contract provides for the consideration payable in that behalf... an express stipulation governing the relations between the parties under a contract, cannot be displaced by assuming that the stipulation is not reasonable.
We, accordingly, agree with the view of the High Court that the Award of the arbitrators was liable to be set aside because of an error apparent on the face of the award.

anchor.surface_text: Relying upon s. 222 of the Indian Contract Act, by which duty to indemnify the agent against the consequences of all lawful acts done in exercise of the authority conferred, is imposed upon the employer, the arbitrators could not award compensation to the agents in excess of the expressly stipulated consideration. The claim made by the Agents was not for indemnity... but a claim for enhancement of the rate of the agreed consideration.
We, accordingly, agree with the view of the High Court that the Award of the arbitrators was liable to be set aside because of an error apparent on the face of the award.

anchor.surface_text: a bar of res judicata by reason of the decision in the Letters Patent Appeal No. 31 of 1953, has, in our judgment, no force. The Subordinate Judge set aside the award on the ground that there had been judicial misconduct committed by the umpire and also on the view that the claims made, as described in Schedules B and D, were not outside the competence of the arbitrators.
We, accordingly, agree with the view of the High Court that the Award of the arbitrators was liable to be set aside because of an error apparent on the face of the award.
